prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6-lines
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral line mapping observations of tracers of the chemistry and dynamics of the protostellar sources and their associated outflow at 0.5'' (120 AU) resolution in Band 6. Our line selection includes molecular outflow tracers, that will enable us to determine the energy budget in the outflow at high sensitivity. While 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) are the most sensitive tracers of the outflowing gas, we have also included a SiO transition as an independent diagnostic of the shock velocity. Our lines from H2CO, SO and CH3OH, will be used to constrain the physical conditions (density, temperature) in the high velocity gas. The setup also includes deuterated species (N2D+, DCO+, DCN and D2CO), which trace the structure and dynamics of the very dense envelope around each protostar. We have also included C18O, SO, 13CS and H213CO, to search for evidence for ice evaporation around each protostar, as a mean to further characterize the past activity. These lines, and especially C18O are expected to diagnose active events in the past which triggered the evaporation of CO from the ices. Such events are not expected to occur in a FHSC but are common in a class 0 YSO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have optimized the correlator setup to cover 14 spectral lines, providing a comprehensive diagnostic of the targeted sources. The expected line width is about 0.6 km/s for the deuterated species, and up to 10 km/s for those tracing the high velocity gas; We therefore request a high spectral resolution but do not need a large velocity coverage. Because of the complex gas dynamics around these sources, with infall signatures and molecular outflows, we need a good spectral resolution on the line profiles. The highest spectral resolution is particularly needed for the deuterated species to detect any velocity signature in the line profiles, as these lines are tracing the dense cores close to the protostar.

The high spectral resolution is needed for the lines tracing the dense and cold material, in order to resolve any velocity signature in the line profiles (e.g. infall). For the species tracing the outflowing gas, with broader line profiles, we have averaged the data to reduce the data rate somewhat.

The largest size corresponds to that of the high velocity gas as mapped by our PdBI observations (Fig 1). We want to approach the size of the pseudo-disk , near 100 AU, which leads to an angular resolution of 0.5" at the Barnard 1b distance (230 pc). We have selected a 7 field mosaic to cover the 2 continuum sources B1b-N and B1b-S and their outflows (see Fig 1).

The spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s, is chosen to follow the gas dynamics including the infall signature and possibly the rotation of the envelope. The line width is about 0.6 km/s in the core and extend to 10 km/s for the outflowing gas. The outflowing gas can then be studied with a coarser spectral resolution (1 to 2 km/s) to increase the S/N. The sensitivity goal has been set to 0.35K (3.8 mJy). Indeed from the work of Hirano and coworkers, and our current PdBI observations, we predict line intensities for DCO+(3-2), DCN(3-2) and N2D+(3-2) larger than 2K in the high density region (n(H2) > 1E6 cm-3) that is our main focus (see Figure 2). We'll reach a brightness sensitivity in the outflow close to 0.1K by smoothing the spectra to 2 km/s. The setup also includes a continuum spectral window which will allow us an easy subtraction of the continuum and a better determination of the SED. With continuum fluxes of > 0.2Jy at 1.3mm at low angular resolution, we shall reach a SNR on the continuum larger than 100 even if some of the flux is resolved (3.8mJy at 0.2 km/s translates to ~ 38 microJy for the continuum band with 2000 km/s width). The sources have remained single down to an angular resolution of 0.5" at 7mm.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band7-cont
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum observations at Band 7 aiming to zoom further in, down to 12 AU (0.05''), to approach the size of the FHSC and to search for possible multiplicity. The current observations performed on these sources indicate that they remain single down to ~ 0.5'' at 7mm. These sources have measured continuum fluxes of about 1Jy at a few arcsec angular resolution at 350 GHz from the SMA and JCMT.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a standard setup for this gaol which uses only continuum.

The current observations performed on these sources indicate that they remain single down to a resolution of 0.5'' at 7mm. We would like to map the structure of the pseudo-disk and determine its inclination. At a resolution of 0.05'', we will get a linear scale of 12AU, approaching the size of the condensed objects and of the launching place of the outflowing matter.

With fluxes approaching 1 Jy at 0.8mm, B1b-N and B1b-S can be mapped with high S/N at 0.05''. Assuming that the flux is homogeneously distributed in 1'', this leads to a flux per beam of 2.5 mJy/beam. With about 1hr, we can reach a noise level of 0.1 mJy leading to a SNR of 25 in this worse case scenario.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to characterize the physical and chemical structure of the First Hydrostatic Core Candidate B1b-N and the nearby young class 0 protostar B1b-S at high spatial resolution with ALMA. These low luminosity sources, located in a dense protostellar core of high column density, drive each a compact molecular outflow with a short dynamical time scale (less than 1000 yrs for B1b-N). Previous studies have confirmed that the observed properties of B1b-N are compatible with a First Hydrostatic Core but could not exclude other hypotheses. ALMA provides the sensitivity and angular resolution to allow zooming both in the continuum (0.05'' or ~12AU) and in carefully selected emission lines probing the dense envelope and the molecular outflows (0.5'' or ~ 120AU), we shall be able to provide a definite answer to the evolutionary stage of B1b-N. The field of view includes the slightly more evolved source B1b-S as a comparison. Our team includes specialists of interferometric observations, chemical modeling and MHD simulations.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Group of Molecular Astrophysics, ICMM CSIC
Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
Submillimeter Astrophysics Group, California Institute of Technology
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
